text.tspan: Age vs.
redshift
Our Universe is expanding, with the space
between galaxies or between glaxy clusters
gradually stretching. The wavelength of light
crossing those spaces also stretches, so that
colors are shifted toward the red end of the
spectrum. Light showing more redshift
comes from farther away, and shows older
objects. Since redshift can be directly
measured, astronomers usually plot historical
information as a function of redshift, rather
than as a function of age, which must be
calculated, and depends on knowing the
values of certain numbers.
Our Universe is expanding, with the space
between galaxies or between glaxy clusters
gradually stretching. The wavelength of light
crossing those spaces also stretches, so that
colors are shifted toward the red end of the
spectrum. Light showing more redshift
comes from farther away, and shows older
objects. Since redshift can be directly
measured, astronomers usually plot historical
information as a function of redshift, rather
than as a function of age, which must be
calculated, and depends on knowing the
values of certain numbers.
After inflation, the expansion
of the Universe either...

g.text: Dark energy and accelerating expansion of the Universe

text.tspan: The Sun
Age: 4.567 Ga; Metallicity (Fe/H) =1, by definition
range of
uncertainty
Immediately after the Big Bang, the matter in the Universe was
essentially all hydrogen and helium. The heavier elements (which
astronomers call “metals”) were generated in stars by nuclear fusion and
spread throughout the galaxies by supernovas — by the explosions of
stars that have used up most of the hydrogen fuel that powers them.
As a result, the
metallicity
of the universe— the content of elements
heavier than helium, has gradually increased through time. The
metallicity of a star is given by the ratio of the number of iron
atoms to hydrogen atoms, divided by the same
ratio in the Sun, whose Fe/H ratio is
defined as 1.
This graph shows an estimate of the increase in
metallicity in the Universe through time, from
Lineweaver, C.H., 2001, An estimate of the age
distribution of terrestrial planets in the universe:
quantifying metallicity as a selection effect: Icarus,
v. 151, p. 307-313, Fig. 2B, with the log scale in
that figure converted to a linear scale.
The history of metallicity is not easy to determine,
and may well be different in different parts of
different galaxies; these problems are reflected in
the wide range of uncertainty in this plot.

g.text: Cosmic events beyond the Milky Way Galaxy

text.tspan: The earliest, most distan`t known explosion, GRB 090423.
(http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/ap090429.html)
Seen as a gamma-ray burst, this may mark the birth of an
early black hole, 13.035 billion years ago, only
630 million years after the Big Bang.
The Dark Age, after the Big Bang, before the first stars — no light was produced
in the Universe, from about 380,000 years to 100 million years after the Big Bang.
The Big Bang
see details below
The earliest, most distant known
explosion, GRB 090423
(http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apo
d/ap090429.html).
Seen as a gamma-ray burst, this
may mark the birth of an early
black hole, 13.035 billion years
ago, only 630 million years after
the Big Bang.
The oldest, most distant known galaxy
(http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/ap090429.html)
with a redshift of 10, appear to us as it was 13.2
billion years ago.
Schematic history of quasar formation, from Fig 2
in Shaver et al., 1996, Decrease in the space density
of quasars at high redshift: Nature, v. 384, p. 439-441.
Cosmic events within the Milky Way
and nearby galaxies
During the he Dark Age, the Milky Way may already have existed as a concentration of gas,
but it did not yet have any stars, and was not yet organized into its barred-spiral form.
Sudden turn-on of star formation in the Larger Magellanic Cloud
(following early star formation and then quiescence from ~12
to ~5 Ga) suggests a dramatic event ~5 Ga: Harris, J., and
Zaritsky, D., 3009, The star formation history of the Large
Magellanic Cloud: Astronomical Journal, v. 138, p. 1243–1260.
redshift
